content_metadata.description: This video focuses on showcasing 10 NBA players who may have been forgotten to have played for the Golden State Warriors.

qAndA.question: Which player on the list was known for revolutionizing the screen and roll play?
Who was the player who got drafted by two different NBA teams and also two ABA teams in the same year?
Which player did the narrator suggest the Warriors should target in the next season?

qAndA.answer: He dunked on Charles Barkley with a behind-the-back move. (Scene 12, around 8:48).
qAndA.question: What memorable dunk did Chris Webber perform during his rookie season with the Warriors?
How many NBA Championships did Robert Parish win with the Boston Celtics?

narrativeProgression.description: Introduction to the topic of remembering NBA players

videoEditingDetails.description: Fast cuts between highlights, glitch effect, upbeat music

activities.description: Narrator speaking over NBA Finals footage

narrativeProgression.description: The narrator introduces the idea of the video series: remembering NBA players who may have been forgotten.
Narrator focuses on the Golden State Warriors for this episode.

videoEditingDetails.description: Transition to black screen, sound of buzzer, cheering crowd.

activities.description: Highlights of Ralph Sampson playing basketball.

narrativeProgression.description: The narrator provides information about Ralph Sampson's career, highlighting his potential and his struggles with injuries.
Mentions Sampson's time with the Golden State Warriors.

scenes.thematicElements: Unfulfilled potential, the impact of injuries on a player's career.
scenes.title: Ralph Sampson's Highlights

videoEditingDetails.description: Vintage footage of Ralph Sampson playing for the Houston Rockets and Golden State Warriors.

activities.description: Highlights of Muggsy Bogues playing basketball, mostly with the Charlotte Hornets.

characterInteraction.description: Bogues is shown interacting with Larry Johnson and Alonzo Mourning, showcasing their chemistry on the court.

narrativeProgression.description: The narrator discusses Muggsy Bogues' career, particularly his time with the Charlotte Hornets and his brief stint with the Golden State Warriors.

videoEditingDetails.description: Footage of Muggsy Bogues playing for various teams, primarily with the Charlotte Hornets.

activities.description: Highlights of Terry Cummings playing basketball, mostly with the Milwaukee Bucks.

narrativeProgression.description: The narrator highlights Terry Cummings' impressive career, emphasizing his scoring ability and his time with the Golden State Warriors.

videoEditingDetails.description: Footage of Terry Cummings playing for the Milwaukee Bucks, San Antonio Spurs, and Golden State Warriors.

activities.description: Highlights of Richard Jefferson playing basketball, mostly with the Cleveland Cavaliers.

characterInteraction.description: Jefferson is shown interacting with LeBron James, showcasing his role in the Cavaliers' team dynamic.

narrativeProgression.description: The narrator discusses Richard Jefferson's time with the Golden State Warriors, contrasting it with his championship win against the Warriors with the Cleveland Cavaliers.

videoEditingDetails.description: Footage of Richard Jefferson playing for the Golden State Warriors and Cleveland Cavaliers, focusing on his role in the Cavaliers' championship win.

activities.description: Highlights of Robert Parish playing basketball, mostly with the Boston Celtics.

characterInteraction.description: Parish is shown interacting with Larry Bird and Kevin McHale, demonstrating the legendary trio's chemistry on the court.

narrativeProgression.description: The narrator details Robert Parish's career, focusing on his dominant time with the Boston Celtics and his surprising early connection with the Golden State Warriors.

scenes.thematicElements: Draft history, team dynamics, unexpected turns in a player's career.
scenes.title: Robert Parish's Career Journey

videoEditingDetails.description: Footage of Robert Parish playing for the Golden State Warriors and Boston Celtics, with emphasis on his championship wins with the Celtics.

activities.description: Highlights of John Starks playing basketball, mostly with the New York Knicks.

characterInteraction.description: Starks is shown alongside Mitch Richmond, illustrating their time together with the Warriors.
Starks is also seen interacting with Kobe Bryant, emphasizing Starks' NBA career context.

narrativeProgression.description: The narrator reveals that John Starks, primarily known for his Knicks career, actually played for the Golden State Warriors on two separate occasions.

scenes.thematicElements: Draft impact, player roles, second chances.
scenes.title: John Starks' Surprise Connection

videoEditingDetails.description: Footage of John Starks playing for the Golden State Warriors and New York Knicks.

activities.description: Highlights of Jamal Crawford playing basketball, mostly with the Atlanta Hawks.

narrativeProgression.description: The narrator discusses Jamal Crawford's brief but productive stint with the Golden State Warriors, noting his starting role despite the team's struggles.

scenes.thematicElements: Player development, career trajectories, draft implications.
scenes.title: Jamal Crawford's Brief Warriors Era

videoEditingDetails.description: Footage of Jamal Crawford playing for the Golden State Warriors and Atlanta Hawks.

activities.description: Highlights of Mark Price playing basketball, mostly with the Cleveland Cavaliers.

narrativeProgression.description: The narrator discusses Mark Price's career, highlighting his time with the Cleveland Cavaliers and his less-known stint with the Golden State Warriors.

scenes.thematicElements: Underrated players, lasting impact, innovative play style.
scenes.title: Mark Price's Underrated Legacy

videoEditingDetails.description: Footage of Mark Price playing for the Cleveland Cavaliers and Golden State Warriors.

activities.description: Highlights of Nick Van Exel playing basketball, mostly with the Los Angeles Lakers.

narrativeProgression.description: The narrator discusses Nick Van Exel's career, particularly his memorable time with the Lakers and his less-remembered time with the Golden State Warriors.

scenes.thematicElements: Career decline, player roles, team context.
scenes.title: Nick Van Exel's Career Overview

videoEditingDetails.description: Footage of Nick Van Exel playing for the Los Angeles Lakers, Denver Nuggets, Dallas Mavericks, and Golden State Warriors.

activities.description: Highlights of Chris Webber playing basketball, mostly with the Sacramento Kings.

characterInteraction.description: Webber is shown interacting with Charles Barkley, showcasing his memorable rookie season dunk.

narrativeProgression.description: The narrator discusses Chris Webber's career, starting with his memorable rookie season with the Golden State Warriors and ending with his unexpected return to finish his career.

scenes.thematicElements: Draft decisions, player-coach relationships, career endings.
scenes.title: Chris Webber's Full Circle

videoEditingDetails.description: Footage of Chris Webber playing for the Golden State Warriors and Sacramento Kings.

activities.description: The narrator speaks over a montage of NBA highlights.

narrativeProgression.description: The narrator concludes the video, thanking viewers and prompting them to subscribe for more content.

videoEditingDetails.description: NBA highlights montage, upbeat music, end screen with "THANKS FOR WATCHING" and "SUBSCRIBE" appearing.

climax.description: Chris Webber's feature as the most well-known player with surprising ties to the Warriors.

storylines.description: Focuses on showcasing 10 NBA players who may have been forgotten to have played for the Golden State Warriors.

content_metadata.title: Forgotten Warriors

trimmingSuggestions.description: Narrator's introduction could be made more concise by removing some gameplay footage.
Focus on Sampson's highlights with the Warriors and shorten the discussion about his Rockets career.
Emphasize the player's highlights with the Warriors and reduce the focus on their careers with other teams.

timecoded_text_to_speech.text: So with the Toronto Raptors and the Golden State Warriors in the NBA finals and almost the
end of the season, I thought of an idea where we look at all 30 teams and look at 10 players
that you may not have known or may have forgotten about who actually played for that certain
team.
So obviously with the Raptors and Warriors heading into game number 6, we're going to
look at both the Raptors and the Warriors, but in this video we're going to look at the
Warriors and in the next episode of this series we'll look at the Raptors.
But I want you guys to let me know which team you want after that and I think it's just
a good way to get some NBA content when it's the off season and there is no basketball
anymore.
So that's the plan for this series.
And this series will be done when we've gone through all 30 NBA teams.
Anyway, before I get started, if you like this idea let me know by hitting that like button
also be sure to comment on which team you'd want me to do next.
So without further ado, let's look at 10 players who you may have forgotten about playing
for the Golden State Warriors and let's see how many of these guys you get right and be
honest in the comment section.
Number 10, Ralph Samson.
He's number 10 but many people don't realize that apart from being one of the top spots
on the What Could Have Been list and the Houston Rockets first overall peak in the 1983
NBA draft, he was also a part of the Golden State Warriors from 1987 till 1989.
He has an incredible size and unnatural agility for a man that was 7 foot 4 is just insane.
He was able to burst on the NBA scene as a rookie averaging 21 points, 11 rebounds, 2 assists,
2 and a half blocks per game in his first season.
He was also named an All Star and won the NBA Rookie of the Year award.
But he was injured halfway into the 1987 88 season which unfortunately was not uncommon
for Samson.
Evident through his name being one that people just remember for What Could Have Been with
Hakeem Allysian one after making the finals in 1986.
The twin towers were meant to do big things but it just wasn't meant to be.
Samson's knee and back troubles worsened and he never played a full season in the remaining
years of his career.
He was only able to average 6.4 points and 5 rebounds with the Golden State Warriors in 1988
Number 9, Muxie Boges.
Everyone loves Muxie.
I mean, how can you not love Muxie Boges?
People remember him for his time in Charlotte with Larry Johnson and Alonzo Morning.
After all, Boges settled in Charlotte.
He established himself in Charlotte as an exceptional passer, a great stealer, one of the fastest
players on the court and a fan favorite.
Boges spent 10 years in Charlotte as a hornet led by Morning and Johnson and they became
one of the most popular teams in the NBA.
But Muxie Boges also played for the Golden State Warriors, averaging 5.5 points and 5 assists
as a warrior and then signed later as a free agent with the Raptors as we all know.
Number 8, Terry Cummings.
If you don't know who Terry Cummings is, you should.
Because in my opinion, he's one of the most underrated players that I know of.
He's a top 50 score of all time.
He was a rookie of the year who averaged 23 points, 10.4 rebounds, which is insane.
He was averaging 16.6 points and 7 rebounds through his 17 year NBA career until he joined
the Warriors in which he averaged 9 points and 5 rebounds a game for his first season
and then 8 points and 5 rebounds in his last season before retiring.
He's obviously best known on his time with the Barks where he made the All-Star team twice
and obviously had a great career with the Spurs as well, but many people forget or don't
even know about him playing for the Golden State Warriors.
Number 7, Richard Jefferson.
This is one of those guys where we just think of him and remember his time in Cleveland
because he won a championship beating the Warriors and it almost seems a little bit weird
seeing him in a Warriors jersey, considering the Cavs Warriors rivalry in the last few
years was insane.
It's one that is just easy to forget.
He even played for them as the average less than 5 points in his time in Golden State.
In the end, he was an integral part of the Cavaliers though.
He actually beat the Warriors despite being down 3 games to 1.
The first team in NBA history to come back being down 3 games to 1.
And Richard Jefferson, even over 35 years old, was a huge part in that team and a great
player coming off the bench and his dunk on Clay Thompson, still insane.
Number 6, Robert Parrish.
Obviously, he was best known for his time at the Celtics.
He spent 14 seasons there and won 4 NBA championship with thanks to Larry Bird, Kevin
Kale and the rest of the team.
But it was also a part of the Warriors.
In fact, they're the team that drafted him.
Parrish was drafted in the first round of the 1976 NBA draft by the Golden State Warriors,
but at that time he had also been drafted by the Utah stars in the 1973 ABA Special League.
And he was also drafted by the Spurs in the 1975 ABA draft as well.
Don't ask me how that works, just go with it.
Parrish signed with the Warriors in the end and the Warriors were NBA champions in 1975.
Two years prior to Parrish's rookie season campaign.
However, when Parrish joined the Warriors, they declined, began immediately.
They missed the entire play was completely from 1978 to 1980.
And then he became a member of the Boston Celtics.
Number 5, John Starks.
Okay, so did you know that Starks played for the Warriors?
If you did, did you know he played for them twice in two different occasions?
Although he was passed over in the 1988 NBA draft, Starks signed with the Golden State
Warriors in September of 1988 as a free agent.
This was his rookie year.
The thing is, if you know the Golden State Warriors, you know that the 1988 draft was a special
one because they drafted Schoengart Mitch Richmond as well with the fifth overall pick.
Which meant that Starks played a limited minute in only 36 games, while Richmond won
rookie of the year.
But in the second cent with the Warriors in 1999, he averaged about 14 points and five
assists and was actually pretty solid before he left.
Number 4, Jamar Crawford.
Because Jamar Crawford has an aged a day since joining the NBA in the year 2000, apart
from a few more tattoos, this image of him in a Warriors jersey almost looks photoshopped.
But it's not.
And to be honest, they're actually a team that should be targeting him again.
Next season.
Crawford only played in 54 games for the Warriors, but he did start in all of them, averaging
nearly 20 points a game with 4.4 assists and 1.5 rebounds.
But because the Warriors did not qualify for the playoffs in the 2008-09 season, they traded
Crawford to the Atlanta Hawks.
The Warriors did go on to draft Curry that year, so I guess it turned out alright.
Number 3.
Mark Price has been known as one of the most underrated point guards of all time.
He's a four time all-star.
He's a two time NBA three point contest winner.
As part of the 50-40-90 club, he's got his jersey retired by the Cleveland Cavaliers.
He was a really, really good player.
He was obviously best known as a Cleveland Cavalier with four of his also appearances
being with the Cavaliers.
And Mark Price actually revolutionized the way that people attack on the screen and
roll.
He was the first guy who really split the screen and roll, and everybody knew that if
they were up against Mark Price, it was going to be a tough night because he was seriously
good.
He actually ended up on the Golden State Warriors in the 1996-1997 NBA season, where he averaged
11 points and 5 assists with a steal per game.
He shot 90% from the free throw line, almost 40% from 3, and about 45% from the field.
So he was extremely efficient just as he was his entire career.
But I reckon a lot of people never knew that Price actually was a warrior at one point.
Number 2.
Nick Van Exel.
This will probably remember Nick Van Exel from his Laker days.
I mean, this guy crossed up players had a smooth left hand jump shot, but Van Exel also
spent some time in Golden State as well.
In fact, he spent 39 games there.
Van Exel was traded in August of 2003 to the Golden State Warriors during the O304 season.
He played in a career low, 39 games, averaging 12.6 points and 5.3 assists.
Van Exel was a veteran by the time he got to the Warriors having spent most of the late
90s with the Lakers and the early 2000s with the Nuggets and the Dallas Mavericks even
before then.
Obviously, it was a big demotion for Van Exel as he went from a playoff contender with
the Dallas Mavericks to a team that had the longest playoff drought in the NBA at the
time.
Which obviously that made Van Exel kind of not want to play for the Warriors, considering
he was almost about to win an NBA championship.
At least try to.
Number 1.
Chris Weber.
Chris Weber.
Now you probably know about Chris Weber playing for the Warriors.
I mean, he got drafted there.
He had a crazy move on Charles Barkley, behind the back, yammed it in his face.
I mean, we all know that the Orlando Magic passed up on Chris Weber and they chose Penny
Hardaway instead, pairing Shack and Penny instead of Shack and Weber.
But this isn't this time.
This isn't the 1993 rookie Chris Weber playing for the Golden State Warriors.
This is the Golden State Warriors Chris Weber of the year 2008.
15 years after he got drafted there, Warriors fans are probably still upset over the fact
that Weber did not play his prime years in Golden State because he immediately after his
rookie season left the team because he didn't like the coach.
Anyway, he finished where he started as he got drafted to Golden State and retired in
Golden State.
He only played nine games for the Warriors averaging 3.9 points, 3.6 rebounds in 14 minutes per
game.
And that's it.
That's 10 players you may have forgotten about playing for the Golden State Warriors and
with that said, if you guys enjoyed this video, please be sure to subscribe for more.
Be sure to leave a like and follow me on Instagram.
